pros: Work life balance and good entry level type of roles for employees
cons: Not a ton of room for growth

pros: The department is a gem, and I have been shielded from the politics and any issues with upper management.
cons: The pay is low and the students' enthusiasm is a bit lacking.

pros: Nice place to work, great people
cons: Challenges that all colleges are currently facing.

pros: The faculty are kind and most departments are friendly and approachable. Students are hard-working and overall willing to put in the work.
cons: Seems there are too many committees and not enough energy/resources to focus on personal research.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Washington, PA
Senior Assistant Director of Admission in Washington, PA
pros: nice campus, fair starting salary, travel expenses covered, decent technology, private offices, good professional building experience
cons: extremely high turnover rate, extensive traveling (pro or con depending on your preference), bit of a rough location

review_title: Not a culture to thrive in...
job_title: Director of Assessment and Institutional Research in Washington, PA
pros: The medical, dental, and eye insurance was fairly good but it didn’t make up for low salaries.
cons:
A very toxic work environment from being dumped on, asked to do unethical work, and retaliation.

The administration seriously lacked empathy and communication skills.

Discrimination and unfairness existed in every aspect of the staff experience. It all mattered to whom your reported and how much power they had.

review_title: I'm glad I no longer work there
pros: My students were pretty good, better than at other places I've taught. My classes were small in size, and I had plenty of support (though I had to go looking for it). My colleagues were generally nice, but they didn't seem too interested in their part-time colleagues (it's the same everywhere).
cons: I never knew if I was going to have classes or not until fairly late and I never got a sense that I was in the running for a full-time position (they did have some full-time adjuncts). It seemed like athletics and student life were valued over academics. I got the sense that attitude came down from the President. I hear from colleagues still there that the work atmosphere has deteriorated incredibly, with the President actively seeking to undermine faculty governance and even her own VPs. I was told recently that she decided not to hire any more tenure-track faculty, just full-time adjuncts, which could be great for me but I don't think that's good overall for the college. There seem to be serious leadership problems and a lack of a clear idea of what direction the college should be heading in. Glad I found work elsewhere.

job_title: Coordinator for Fraternity and Sorority Life in Washington, PA
cons: Toxic Work environment and no support from superiors

review_title: The future does not look bright
pros: Being a college professor is general is great. I am given a lot of freedom in what and how I teach, and I have time to pursue my scholarly and personal interests. Though our benefits are good (for now at least), faculty salaries are a problem (not that the administration cares).
cons: W&J has significant problems in terms of its finances. Our endowment is nowhere near what it should be for a college of our history and prestige. We are far too tuition-dependent, but we haven't undertaken a capital campaign in  far too long. The president just wants to put up buildings. Do we really need a new expensive addition to our gym when we have too academic buildings sitting empty? What are our priorities? They don't seem to include academics. The president is also obsessed with eliminating tenure, and is now taking a backdoor approach by eliminating tenure-track hires. Things are looking bleak, and people are fleeing left and right. I think they feel the ship is sinking.

review_title: W&J used to be a great place to work
pros: The faculty, staff and students are great. The proximity to Pittsburgh is a big plus. Nearly everyone takes the college's academic mission to heart and genuinely cares about educating our students.
cons: There are serious problems with the management of this college, and they all stem from the top. Funds are not allocated in ways that make a bit of sense, with money being wasted on frivolous projects while important things are ignored. The president seems to view the faculty and staff with contempt, except for a few favorites. This used to be an amazing, collegial place to work but has definitely become less enjoyable over the past eight years.

job_title: Tutor and Newspaper Editor in Washington, PA
pros: Close-knit group of employees when you work a student position. Most supervisors are easily accessible through email and are friendly and easy to work with. The job was manageable within the amount of extra time you will have as a student and was nice if you just want to have a little bit of extra money.
cons: Pay isn't that great, but at $8 an hour it's more than minimum wage (again, this was a student position, not an administrative one). If you want to make a lot of money and work a lot of hours, look for a job in the city of Washington instead of getting a student job where you will be capped at working 10 hours a week.

pros: Small school, friendly students, nice staff located in a fairly safe town in western Pennsylvania.  Students were probably average to above average in intelligence.
cons: I was an adjunct there in modern languages.  Adjuncts are treated like hired hands --especially in French and Spanish.  Your classes will be observed and your tests must be approved before you can give them.  It was not a good situation and did not end well.  I left with pleasure after one year.

job_title: Information Desk Employee in Washington, PA
pros: Very understanding of education responsibilities. Since it's a work study job, we are able to take the time off we need to succeed in our courses.
cons: Not many hours available, too many students and not enough jobs.

cons: Pay is not great compared to job market
